sen.j: 久邇宮朝彦親王（くにのみや あさひこしんのう、文政7年2月27日 (旧暦)（1824年3月27日） - 明治24年（1891年）10月25日）は、幕末から明治時代初期の皇族。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Kuni-no-miya Asahiko (Feb. 27, 1824, in the lunar calendar, to Oct. 25, 1891) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the closing days of the Tokugawa Shogunate to the early part of the Meiji Era.

Prince Kuni Asahiko (Feb. 27, 1824, in the lunar calendar, to Oct. 25, 1891) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the closing days of the Tokugawa Shogunate and the early part of the Meiji Era.

Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko (March 27, 1824 to October 25, 1891) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the closing days of the Tokugawa Shogunate and the early part of the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を削除し、原文の西暦に基づき表記を修正、Oct.→October、the Meiji Era→the Meiji periodとしました。

sen.e: In 1838, he entered the Buddhist priesthood, was granted "Sonno" as his "imina" (lit. 'name to avoid,' a kind of private name, tabooed out of respect while alive), and assigned as the head priest of Ichijoin subtemple of Kofuku-ji Temple in Nara.

As Seirenin was a temple headed by Imperial Princes and located at Awataguchi, he was known by the traditional names Shorenin-no-miya and Awata-no-miya.

sen.j: 尊融法親王は日米修好通商条約の勅許に反対し、将軍徳川家定の後継者問題では徳川慶喜を支持したことなどから大老井伊直弼に目を付けられ、安政6年（1859年）には安政の大獄で「隠居永蟄居」を命じられる。
sen.e: Since Sonyu Hosshinno (Imperial Prince Sonyu) opposed the Imperial sanction of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan and supported Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA when discussion was made on who to succeed Iesada TOKUGAWA, he was considered as a persona non grata for Naosuke II, chief minister of the Tokugawa Shogunate government, he was ordered to abdication and life incarceration (Inkyo eichikkyo) by Ii at the time of Ansei Purge in 1859.

In 1859, during the Ansei Purge that resulted from the question of who should succeed Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, Tairo (chief minister) Naosuke II condemned Prince Sonyu (Asahiko), who opposed the Court's sanctioning of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan and supported Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, to perpetual confinement(Inkyo eichikkyo).

In 1859, during the Ansei Purge that resulted from the question of who should succeed Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, Tairo (chief minister) Naosuke II condemned Cloistered Imperial Prince Sonyu (Asahiko), who opposed the Court's sanctioning of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan and supported Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, to perpetual confinement (Inkyo eichikkyo).
sen.cmt: 尊融法親王→Cloistered Imperial Prince Sonyuとし、スペースを追加

sen.j: このため青蓮院宮を名乗れなくなった尊融法親王は、相国寺塔頭の桂芳軒に幽居して獅子王院宮と称した。
sen.e: Since this treatment disqualified him from the title Seirenin-no-miya, Imperial Prince Sonyu lived in seclusion at Keihoken, a subtemple of Shokoku-ji Temple and adopted the name Shishioin-no-miya.
Since this treatment disqualified him from the title Seirenin-no-miya, Prince Sonyu lived in seclusion at Keihoken, a subtemple of Shokoku-ji Temple and adopted the name Shishioin-no-miya.
Since this treatment disqualified him from the title Shorenin no miya, Prince Sonyu lived in seclusion at Keihoken, a subtemple of Shokoku-ji Temple and adopted the name Shishioinnomiya.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）に赦免されて復帰した尊融法親王は、同年には国事御用掛として朝政に参画、翌・文久3年（1863年）8月27日 (旧暦)には還俗して中川宮の宮号を名乗る。
sen.e: In 1862, Imperial Prince Sonyu was pardoned and regained his former title, and in the same year he joined the political operations of the Imperial Court as Kokuji Goyogakari (state affairs official).

sen.j: 翌・文久3年（1863年）8月27日 (旧暦)には還俗して中川宮の宮号を名乗る。
sen.e: On August 27 (lunar calendar) in 1863, he left the priesthood and adopted a "miya-go," a name granted for an independent Imperial family, Nakagawa-no-miya.

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）前半は長州藩系公卿を中心とした討幕・尊攘派が朝廷の主流であった。
sen.e: In the first half of 1863, the court nobles with ties to the Choshu clan, who were classified as an Tobaku Sonjo-ha (lit. anti-shogunate, pro-Emperor, pro-foreigner-expulsion faction) (hereinafter abbreviated as "anti-shogunate" faction), were the mainstream group in the Imperial Court.

In the first half of 1863, court nobles with ties to the Choshu clan, who were known as the Tobaku Sonjo-ha (lit. anti-shogunate, pro-Emperor, pro-foreigner-expulsion faction), were the dominant group in the Imperial Court.

In the first half of 1863, court nobles with ties to the Choshu clan, who were known as the Tobaku Sonjo-ha (lit. anti-shogunate, pro-Emperor, pro-foreigner-expulsion faction), were the dominant group in the Imperial Court.

sen.j: そして、尊攘討幕派の志士たちの朝廷工作活動は、いかに朝廷に幕府を制御させるかという点に目標が移っていた。
sen.e: As they engaged in lobby activity in the Imperial Court, anti-shogunate samurai were focusing their attention to how to make the Imperial Court manipulate the Tokugawa Shogunate.

sen.j: それが大和行幸の詔であった。

This resulted in the Imperial edict, Yamato Gyoko (the Imperial Trip to the Province of Yamato).

sen.j: 孝明天皇の大和行幸の際に、天皇自ら攘夷のための軍議を開き、軍議を開くことによって自動的に幕府から軍事権および施政権を取り返すということを企てていた。
sen.e: The plan was that Emperor Komei himself would hold a meeting on military actions for the purpose of expulsion of foreigners during the Imperial visit to Yamato and automatically regain the power of military action and the right to administration from the Tokugawa Shogunate by holding such meeting itself.

The plan was that Emperor Komei, during the Imperial visit to Yamato, would hold a meeting on military actions for the purpose of expulsion of foreigners, thereby gaining control of the military and the government from the Tokugawa Shogunate.

sen.e: The plan was that Emperor Komei, during the Imperial visit to Yamato, would hold a meeting on military actions for the purpose of expulsion of foreigners, thereby gaining control of the military and the government from the Tokugawa Shogunate.

sen.j: 同時に、征夷大将軍が率いる幕府軍こそ最も攘夷を実行すべき責任があり、当然取るべき責任を取ってもらうという算段でもあった。
sen.e: At the same time, their strategy was to make sure that the Shogunate forces led by Seii Taishogun (Barbarian-subduing Generalissimo, title given to the shogun) would be the very person responsible for expelling foreigners and should take the consequences.

sen.j: 公武合体派の領袖であった尊融親王は長州派公卿や尊攘討幕派の志士たちから嫌われ、真木保臣らの画策によって「西国鎮撫使」の名のもと、都から遠ざけられかけもした。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Sonyu, who was the leader of Kobu-gattai-ha (lit. court and shogunate unification faction), was avoided by pro-Choshu nobles and anti-Shogunate samurai and was about to be forced to stay away from Kyoto under the name of the Envoy to Pacify the Western Regions, a scheme designed by Yasuomi MAKI.

Prince Sonyu, who was the leader of the Kobu-gattai-ha (lit. court and shogunate unification faction), was avoided by pro-Choshu nobles and anti-Shogunate samurai and was about to be forced to stay away from Kyoto as the Envoy to Pacify the Western Regions, a scheme designed by Yasuomi MAKI.

Imperial Prince Sonyu, who was the leader of the Kobu-gattai-ha (lit. court and shogunate unification faction), was avoided by pro-Choshu nobles and anti-Shogunate samurai and was about to be forced to stay away from Kyoto as the Envoy to Pacify the Western Regions, a scheme designed by Yasuomi MAKI.
sen.cmt: Prince Sonyu→Imperial Prince Sonyuとしました。

sen.j: これを察知した親王は西国鎮撫使の就任を固辞し、政敵であり長州派公卿の有力者であった大宰帥・有栖川宮熾仁親王にその役目を押し付けた。
sen.e: Aware of the true intension behind the scheme, he rejected the order to serve as the Envoy and pushed the role to Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Taruhito, a powerful leader of pro-Choshu nobles and Dazai-no-sochi (Governor-General of Dazaifu, the local government office in Kyushu), who was his political foe.

Aware of the true intention behind the scheme, he refused to serve as the Envoy and handed the role to his political opponent, Prince Arisugawa Taruhito, a powerful leader of pro-Choshu nobles and the Dazai-no-sochi (Governor-General of Dazaifu, the local government office in Kyushu).
sen.cmt: Spelling of "intention""rejected the order"→"refused""pushed"→"handed"Deleted "Imperial", "-no-miya"Added "the"", who was his political foe"→"his political opponent," and moved
sen.e: Aware of the true intention behind the scheme, he refused to serve as the Envoy and handed the role to his political opponent, Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito, a powerful leader of pro-Choshu nobles and the Dazai no sochi (Governor-General of Dazaifu, the local government office in Kyushu).
sen.cmt: Prince Arisugawa Taruhito→Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhitoとし、ハイフンをとりDazai no sochiとしました。

sen.j: さらに尊融親王は京都守護職を務める会津藩やこの時期会津藩と友好関係にあった薩摩藩と手を結び、急進的な倒幕と攘夷決行を唱える長州派公卿と長州藩を京から排除しようとし、彼らを嫌い幕府を信頼していた孝明天皇から内意を引き出し、八月十八日の政変を行う。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Sonyu also partnered with the Aizu clan, which served the role of Kyoto Shugoshoku (Military Commissioner of Kyoto), and the Satsuma clan, which was in friendly terms with the Aizu clan at that time, and staged the August 18 Deportation, which expelled pro-Choshu court nobles and the Choshu clan who advocated drastic destruction of the Tokugawa Shogunate and expulsion of foreign forces, from Kyoto with the previously obtained unofficial approval for such a political change from Emperor Komei who didn't like the Choshu clan and trusted the Shogunate government.

sen.j: 八月十八日の政変により長州派公卿および長州藩が朝廷から退くと、朝彦親王は京都守護職松平容保とともに孝明天皇の信任を篤く受けるが、これは同時に、下野した長州藩士や倒幕・尊攘派の志士たちの強烈な恨みを買うことにもなる。
sen.e: After pro-Choshu court nobles and the Choshu clan were removed from the Imperial government by the August 18 Deportation, Imperial Prince Asahiko and Military Commissioner of Kyoto Katamori MATSUDAIRA were deeply trusted by Emperor Komei, but this created a strong sense of bitterness and rancor in the Choshu clan samurai and anti-Shogunate samurai who stepped down from office.

sen.e: Following the removal of pro-Choshu court nobles and the Choshu clan from the Imperial government in the August 18 Deportation, Prince Asahiko and Military Commissioner of Kyoto Katamori MATSUDAIRA gained the trust of Emperor Komei, but this created a strong sense of bitterness and rancor in the Choshu clan samurai and anti-Shogunate samurai, who stepped down from office.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）、一部の尊攘倒幕派は朝彦親王邸への放火や容保の殺害を計画、長州藩と長州派公卿との連絡役でもあった武器商人の古高俊太郎に大量の武器を用意させた。
sen.e: In 1864, some anti-Shogunate samurai planned to set fire to the residence of Imperial Prince Asahiko and murder Katamori and had Shuntaro FURUTAKA, an arms dealer who also served as a liaison between the Choshu clan and pro-Choshu nobles, procure a large number of weapons.

In 1864, some anti-Shogunate samurai, planning to set fire to the residence of Prince Asahiko and murder Katamori, had Shuntaro FURUTAKA, an arms dealer who also served as a liaison between the Choshu clan and pro-Choshu nobles, procure a large number of weapons.

In 1864, some anti-Shogunate samurai, planning to set fire to the residence of Imperial Prince Asahiko and murder Katamori, had Shuntaro FURUTAKA, an arms dealer who also served as a liaison between the Choshu clan and pro-Choshu nobles, procure a large number of weapons.

sen.j: しかし、実行寸前で古高が新撰組に捕らえられ、計画に関与していた者の多くが池田屋事件で闘死、もしくは捕縛された。
sen.e: But immediately before implementation of the plan, Furutaka was arrested by Shinsengumi, and many people involved in the scheme were killed or arrested at the Ikedaya Incident.

But immediately before the implementation of the plan, Furutaka was arrested by the Shinsengumi, and many of the people involved in the scheme were killed or arrested in what was known as the Ikedaya Incident.

sen.j: この年、宮号を中川宮から賀陽宮（かやのみや）に改めた。
